e4: Continuing a policy of knowingly biased reporting, even if investors adjust for it, creates an ethical dilemma. Transparency builds trust with all investors in the long run. While there might be short-term market fluctuations from the change, ultimately acting ethically is crucial for a sustainable and reputable company.
e5: An ethical reporting policy prioritizes accuracy, transparency, and completeness. It avoids misleading language or manipulations that could obscure the true financial picture. Importantly, it communicates information clearly and consistently so that all investors have access to reliable data for informed decision-making. While short-term considerations might arise from a policy change, long-term trust and reputation are built on ethical reporting practices.
e6: Yes, I would have some follow-up questions for the management team.  Specifically, I'd want to understand: 1) What plans are in place to communicate the policy shift to investors clearly and proactively?  2) How will we address potential confusion among retail investors who may not be aware of the previous bias? 3) Do we have data to support the claim that the short-term market impact from switching to honest reporting will be minimal?
